Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: The effects of light level and color vision on the foraging behavior of cathemeral red-bellied lemurs (Eulemur rubriventer)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Humans and many other primates have trichromatic color vision, which confers the ability to discriminate between long (e.g., red) and middle (e.g., green) wavelength chromaticities. Among placental mammals, this feature is unique to primates, but the underlying genetic basis for trichromacy varies across lineages. Importantly, the selective pressures favoring the evolution of trichromacy are still being discussed.

In humans, Old World monkeys and apes, as well as Neotropical howler monkeys, most individuals in a population have the capacity for trichromatic color vision. In contrast, most Neotropical monkeys and Malagasy lemurs maintain a sex-linked polymorphism, which provides only heterozygous females the potential for trichromacy, while all males and homozygous females are red-green color blind (dichromatic). This situation provides a unique opportunity to investigate the potential advantages and disadvantages to having trichromatic and dichromatic color vision. For example, it has long been hypothesized that trichromats have an advantage over dichromats when foraging on red-colored food. Empirical support for trichromatic foraging advantages, however, particularly in wild populations, is limited. Recent studies suggest that trichromats might experience more pronounced foraging advantages under dim light, such as during dawn and dusk, rather than under bright light levels.

Research conducted by doctoral student Rachel Jacobs (Stony Brook University), supervised by Dr. Patricia Wright, tests hypotheses that different types of color vision confer foraging advantages under bright or dim light conditions in a wild population of polymorphic and cathemeral (active throughout a 24-hour day) red-bellied lemurs (Eulemur rubriventer) in Ranomafana National Park, Madagascar. These hypotheses are tested using a combination of 1) systematic behavioral data collection, 2) genetic analyses to determine individual color vision status (behavioral observers will be unaware of the status), and 3) color measurements using reflectance spectra of red-bellied lemur food items. This research addresses long-held hypotheses regarding the adaptive significance of trichromatic and polymorphic color vision in primates. On a broader scale, this project provides training for a Malagasy student and local Malagasy villagers, supports multiple national and international collaborations, and is initiating a large-scale research effort on red-bellied lemurs, greatly facilitating future research on this species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among mammals, primates are uniquely variable in their color vision capacities. While some species, such as humans and great apes, have trichromatic color vision, which allows the ability to discriminate colors in the long (e.g., red) and middle (e.g., green) wavelength range of light, many species are dichromatic, or red-green color blind. Still other species are polymorphic and maintain both trichromatic individuals and dichromatic individuals within the same population. This condition results from having two or more variants (medium and long wavelength –M/L- alleles) of the sex-linked M/L opsin gene. The ultimate causes of this variation both within and across species are currently unknown, but multiple hypotheses suggest that trichromacy and/or dichromacy may provide foraging advantages in the form of detecting “red” food items (trichromacy) or detecting camouflaged food items (dichromacy). It has also been suggested that such advantages may be more pronounced under dim light conditions. This project is exploring adaptive hypotheses (related to foraging behavior and light level) for the evolution of color vision in red-bellied lemurs (Eulemur rubriventer) in Ranomafana National Park (RNP), Madagascar.

Color vision is particularly variable in lemurs. While some species exhibit polymorphic color vision, many lemurs are strictly dichromatic, usually exhibiting the medium wavelength allele. Results from this project unexpectedly found that red-bellied lemurs in RNP are unique among members of the genus Eulemur for which color vision data are available. While other Eulemur species are either polymorphic or dichromatic with the medium wavelength allele, the red-bellied lemur population in RNP is strictly dichromatic with the long wavelength allele. This result suggests that there may have been directional selection favoring the long wavelength allele in this lineage or relaxed selection resulting in allele loss due to genetic drift. During this project, multiple data were collected on the red-bellied lemur population in RNP, including genetic data (using fecal samples), foraging behavior data, and data on the color of food items consumed (measured using a spectrometer). Data analysis is currently ongoing, but this project is exploring potential adaptive explanations for this result, as well as nonadaptive explanations (allele loss due to drift), which have been proposed but rarely addressed. This project is providing new insights into how different evolutionary mechanisms may play a role in the distribution of color vision variation observed in primates.

This project has also had multiple broader impacts. This study initiated an unprecedented large-scale research effort on the pair-living red-bellied lemur in RNP. During the course of this study, genetic samples and demographic data for >150 individuals in >40 groups of red-bellied lemurs were collected. Photographs of individuals were also collected when possible for individual identification. These data have helped to stimulate new research ideas and forge new collaborations across multiple institutions.   

During this project, multiple undergraduate (or post-graduate) women, local Malagasy villagers, and one student from the University of Antananarivo in Madagascar were trained and participated in behavioral data collection techniques in Madagascar. Multiple graduate and undergraduate students were also trained in genetic methods.
